title: Question on shap value distribution
body:
First of all, thanks for the great package. I found some really interesting things using it recently to unstack ensemble models and explain what is happening under the hood. 

Already searched all issues but still had a question on a regression problem where the y data set range was from 60,000 - 700,000.

In your paper you state:

> This method requires retraining the model on all feature subsets S ⊆ F, where F is the set of all
features. It assigns an importance value to each feature that represents the effect on the model
prediction of including that feature. To compute this effect, a model fS∪{i} is trained with that feature
present, and another model fS is trained with the feature withheld. Then, predictions from the two
models are compared on the current input fS∪{i}(xS∪{i}) − fS(xS), where xS represents the values
of the input features in the set S. Since the effect of withholding a feature depends on other features
in the model, the preceding differences are computed for all possible subsets S ⊆ F \ {i}. The
Shapley values are then computed and used as feature attributions. They are a weighted average of all
possible differences:


So for the distribution of shap values - I am getting a little confused as it pertains to the paper and the distribution. If the weighted average of all possible differences is computed, how to explain a single point on the chart below and the resultant distributions?

The confusion arises when it is described in the package that the values represent a large(r) number as it relates to the impact on the model; e.g ExterQual_TA  (low quality ) has a negative effect on the model with the binary value whereas OverallQual has a positive effect on the model. I am having trouble to explain the distribution. For example, what the is the meaning of the binary values range in a regression problem?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17535345/48301985-22409b00-e4ab-11e8-90c9-3a8d285f2ce7.png)
